whatIsMBTI.title: What is MBTI?
whatIsMBTI.p1: The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) is one of the world's most popular personality frameworks. It was developed by Katharine Cook Briggs and her daughter Isabel Briggs Myers, based on the psychological types proposed by Carl Jung in the early 20th century.
whatIsMBTI.p2: MBTI sorts people into 16 personality types using four pairs of opposite preferences: Extraversion (E) vs Introversion (I), Sensing (S) vs Intuition (N), Thinking (T) vs Feeling (F), and Judging (J) vs Perceiving (P). Each type reflects how you prefer to focus your energy, take in information, make decisions, and organize your life.
whatIsMBTI.p3: Understanding your type can help you recognize your strengths, communication style, and how you work with others. Many people use it for self-awareness, career exploration, and improving relationships.
whatIsMBTI.p4: This site offers a free, quick MBTI-style test that takes about 1–2 minutes. It uses a decision-tree approach: a short series of questions that narrow down to the type that best fits your answers. For in-depth guides on the four dimensions and how to use your result, visit our Articles section.

sixteenTypes.title: The 16 Personality Types
sixteenTypes.intro: The 16 types are combinations of the four letters (e.g. INFP, ESTJ). Each type has a distinct pattern of preferences and is often given a descriptive name (e.g. Architect for INTJ, Campaigner for ENFP). Our test guides you through a short decision tree to find the type that best fits your answers.

whyTakeTest.title: Why Take This Test?
whyTakeTest.p1: Our free MBTI-style test is designed for anyone curious about personality types—whether you are new to the framework or want a quick way to revisit your preferences. It takes about 1–2 minutes and gives you a result you can explore with full type descriptions, strengths, and tips for using your type in daily life.
whyTakeTest.p2: You can use your result for self-reflection, conversation starters with friends, or as a springboard to read our articles on the four dimensions and how to apply MBTI in relationships and work. No account or email is required; your answers stay in your browser.

about.title: About MBTI
about.description: The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) is a personality assessment tool that categorizes individuals into 16 distinct personality types based on four dimensions: Extraversion/Introversion, Sensing/Intuition, Thinking/Feeling, and Judging/Perceiving.
about.aboutThisSiteContent: MBTI Quick Test is a free, ad-supported website that offers a short personality test and educational content about the 16 MBTI types. Our goal is to make the framework accessible and fun: you can take the test in 1–2 minutes, read about your type, and explore articles on the four dimensions and how to use your result. We do not collect or store your answers; all processing happens in your browser. For policy and contact information, see our Privacy Policy, Terms of Use, and Contact pages.
about.disclaimer: This is a quick test for entertainment purposes. For professional assessment, please consult certified MBTI practitioners.
about.privacyText: We do not store your test results. All data is processed locally in your browser.
about.historyContent: Katharine Cook Briggs and her daughter Isabel Briggs Myers developed the MBTI during and after World War II, inspired by Carl Jung's book Psychological Types (1921). They wanted to make Jung's ideas accessible and useful for everyday people. The indicator was first published in 1962 and has since been updated and used in education, career development, and team building.
about.dimensionsContent: MBTI uses four pairs of opposite preferences. Extraversion (E) vs Introversion (I) describes where you get energy—from the outer world or your inner world. Sensing (S) vs Intuition (N) describes how you take in information—through concrete details or patterns and possibilities. Thinking (T) vs Feeling (F) describes how you make decisions—by logic or by values and impact on people. Judging (J) vs Perceiving (P) describes how you organize your life—with structure and closure or with flexibility and openness.
about.useCasesContent: People use MBTI for self-awareness, career exploration, improving communication in relationships and teams, and understanding differences in learning and work styles. It is not a measure of skill or intelligence—it describes preferences, not abilities. No type is better or worse; each has strengths and growth areas.

answers.whatIsMBTIAnswer: MBTI (Myers-Briggs Type Indicator) is a personality assessment tool based on Carl Jung's psychological types. It categorizes people into 16 personality types using four dimensions: Introversion/Extraversion, Sensing/Intuition, Thinking/Feeling, and Judging/Perceiving. Each dimension describes a preference (e.g. where you get energy, how you take in information), and the four letters together form your type. Our site offers a short, free test that uses a decision tree to suggest the type that best fits your answers, plus articles and descriptions to help you learn more.
answers.howAccurateAnswer: This is a quick test designed for entertainment and self-discovery. It uses a decision tree: your answers to a series of questions narrow down to one of the 16 types. While that method can give consistent and meaningful results, it is not a replacement for the full, official MBTI assessment or professional psychological evaluation. Results may vary with context and over time. We recommend using your result as a starting point for self-reflection and as a way to explore the 16 types—not as a final label.
answers.howLongAnswer: The test typically takes 1-2 minutes to complete. It consists of a series of yes/no style questions that guide you through a decision tree to determine your MBTI type.
answers.freeToUseAnswer: Yes, this test is completely free to use. There are no hidden fees or subscriptions required.
answers.saveResultsAnswer: No, we do not save your test results. All processing happens locally in your browser, and your results are never transmitted to our servers. You can share your results manually if you choose.
answers.differentResultsAnswer: Personality can be fluid and context-dependent. Different results may reflect different aspects of your personality or changes over time. This is normal and part of the complexity of human personality.
answers.professionalUseAnswer: This test is designed for entertainment and personal insight only. It is not validated for hiring, clinical diagnosis, or formal assessment. If you need results for career counseling, team building, or mental health purposes, please use the official MBTI instrument administered by a certified practitioner or seek a licensed psychologist. Our content and test are meant to help you learn about personality types in a fun, low-pressure way.

understandingResults.title: Understanding Your MBTI Result
understandingResults.description: How to interpret and use your personality type for self-awareness, relationships, and career.
understandingResults.intro: Your MBTI result is a starting point for self-discovery. Here's how to make the most of it.

interpretation.heading: How to Interpret Your Type
interpretation.p1: Your four-letter type (e.g. INFP, ESTJ) reflects your preferences on four dimensions: where you get energy, how you take in information, how you make decisions, and how you organize your life. No type is better or worse—each has strengths and growth areas.
interpretation.p2: Read the full description and strengths on your result page. If something doesn't fit, that's normal: the MBTI describes tendencies, not every situation. Use it as a lens for reflection, not a fixed label.

selfAwareness.heading: Self-Awareness and Growth
selfAwareness.p1: Knowing your type can help you honor your needs. Introverts may need quiet time to recharge; Judgers may work best with clear deadlines. When you notice stress or conflict, your type can offer clues about what might be missing (e.g. flexibility, clarity, or connection).
selfAwareness.p2: You can develop skills in any dimension. The MBTI shows what comes naturally; it doesn't limit what you can learn or become.

relationships.heading: Relationships and Communication
relationships.p1: Type differences often explain why people clash or connect. For example, Thinkers may focus on logic first while Feelers consider impact on people. Sensors may want concrete details while Intuitives prefer the big picture.
relationships.p2: Understanding these differences can reduce frustration and improve teamwork, family dynamics, and friendships. Share your type with others as a way to explain your style, not to stereotype.

career.heading: Career and Learning
career.p1: Many people use the MBTI to explore careers and learning styles. Some types gravitate toward roles that involve analysis, structure, or people; others toward creativity or flexibility. Use your result to explore options that fit your preferences.
career.p2: Remember: your type describes preferences, not abilities. You can succeed in any field; the MBTI simply helps you understand how you might learn and work best.

nextSteps.heading: Next Steps
nextSteps.p1: Take a look at our Articles section for deeper guides on the four dimensions, the history of the MBTI, and how to use your result in daily life. You can also browse all 16 personality types to compare and learn about other types.
nextSteps.p2: Revisit your result from time to time. As you learn more about yourself, your understanding of your type may deepen—and that's exactly what the MBTI is for.
